docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Horizon Group, through its subsidiaries Horizon Air Freight and Swift Marine, is a leading global provider of specialised international freight forwarding and one of the world’s leading logistics companies. Operating out of over 30 locations across the Americas, Europe, and Asia, our platform navigator offers services spanning multimodal logistics for marine spares, supplies, and equipment and port agency solutions.

Integration APIs are using a set of standard interfaces to send and receive information regarding the international forwarding operations to and from our customers. Based on these interfaces, which are designed, implemented and maintained on a global basis, the information transfer between systems is reliable and effective.

docs.title: Objectives
docs.text:
The goals of this documentation are to:

  • Describe the available APIs exposed
  • Define terminology and domain concepts used across the platform
  • Explain how to authenticate, invoke, and consume the APIs
  • Provide visibility into API evolution through releases and changelogs
  • Establish clear contractual expectations for integrators

This documentation is intended for:

  • Internal development teams and consultants
  • Integration engineers and DevOps teams
  • External partners with authorised API access

docs.title: Structure Overview
docs.text:
The documentation is organised into logical domains, each exposing a set of endpoints related to a specific business capability (for example: orders, shipments, documents, events, or reference data). At a high level, the documentation site is structured as follows:

  • HOME: General concepts, terminology, and usage guidelines.
  • API CATALOGUE: Detailed reference documentation for each available API, including endpoints, request/response schemas, and examples.
  • RELEASES: A chronological record of API changes, including new features, improvements, deprecations, and breaking changes.

docs.title: Terminology
docs.text:
The following terms are used consistently throughout the documentation:

Term Description API Consumer Any system or service that invokes Navigator APIs Resource A business entity exposed by the API (e.g. Order, Shipment, Document) Endpoint A specific HTTP path and method used to interact with a resource Payload The JSON body sent in a request or returned in a response Version The version identifier of an API or release Release A published set of API changes deployed to an environment

Additional domain-specific terminology is defined within each API section where relevant.

docs.title: Environments
docs.text:
Navigator APIs may be available in multiple environments, such as:

  • TEST - test.api.swift-navigator.com
  • LIVE - live.api.swift-navigator.com

Each environment has:

  • Its own base URL
  • Isolated data
  • Independent release cadence

Environment-specific details are documented where applicable in the API reference.

docs.title: Versioning Strategy
docs.text:
Navigator APIs follow a versioned API strategy to ensure stability and predictability.

Key points:

  • Versions are explicitly defined and documented
  • Non-breaking changes may be introduced within a version
  • Breaking changes result in a new version or are clearly communicated in advance
  • Deprecated endpoints are announced and tracked in the Releases section

Specific versioning rules are described in the relevant API sections.

docs.title: Authentication and Authorisation
docs.text:
All Navigator APIs are protected and require authentication.

At a high level:

  • Requests must include valid credentials
  • Access is scoped based on the consumer’s permissions
  • Unauthorised or insufficiently scoped requests are rejected

Detailed authentication flows, headers, and examples are provided in the API reference.

docs.title: Data Formats and Conventions
docs.text:
Unless explicitly stated otherwise:

  • APIs use JSON for request and response bodies
  • UTF-8 encoding is assumed
  • Timestamps are expressed in ISO 8601 format (UTC)
  • HTTP status codes are used according to standard semantics

Common conventions for pagination, filtering, sorting, and error responses are documented once and reused across APIs.

docs.title: How to Use This Documentation
docs.text:
For new integrators:

  1. Start with this Introduction section
  2. Review authentication and environment setup
  3. Navigate to the relevant API domain
  4. Refer to the Releases section to track changes

For existing integrators:

  • Regularly review the Releases section
  • Monitor deprecations and upcoming breaking changes

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
All APIs in this documentation expose a contract-driven, integration-first interface to the company’s logistics platform.

Key points to keep in mind when integrating:

  • APIs are designed for system-to-system consumption, not UI-driven usage.
  • API catalogue is organised by business domain, with shared conventions across all endpoints.
  • Both synchronous (request/response) and asynchronous (eventual, state-driven) interaction models are supported.
  • All APIs are versioned, secured, and evolve through explicitly documented releases.
  • Behaviour not explicitly documented should be considered unsupported.
  • Consumers are expected to treat the APIs as long-lived contracts, track releases proactively, and design integrations that tolerate partial failure, retries, and eventual consistency where applicable.

docs.title: References
docs.text: Page Reference: [docs/index.md]

docs.title: Basic Considerations
docs.text:
Before implementing an integration with the APIs, developers should familiarise themselves with the available environments and their intended purpose. Each environment supports a different phase of the integration lifecycle, from early development and validation to production usage.

Selecting the appropriate environment and understanding its characteristics upfront helps ensure predictable behaviour, safer testing, and smoother promotion of changes through to live operation.

docs.title: Environments
docs.text:
Navigator APIs may be available in multiple environments, such as:

  • MOCK - mock.api.swift-navigator.com
  • TEST - test.api.swift-navigator.com
  • LIVE - live.api.swift-navigator.com

Each environment has:

  • Its own base URL
  • Isolated data
  • Independent release cadence

Environment-specific details are documented where applicable in the API reference.

docs.title: Authentication and Authorisation
docs.text:
All Navigator APIs are protected and require authentication.

At a high level:

  • Requests must include valid credentials
  • Access is scoped based on the consumer’s permissions
  • Unauthorised or insufficiently scoped requests are rejected

Detailed authentication flows, headers, and examples are provided in the API reference.

docs.title: Data Formats and Conventions
docs.text:
Unless explicitly stated otherwise:

  • APIs use JSON for request and response bodies
  • UTF-8 encoding is assumed
  • Timestamps are expressed in ISO 8601 format (UTC)
  • HTTP status codes are used according to standard semantics

Common conventions for pagination, filtering, sorting, and error responses are documented once and reused across APIs.

docs.title: References
docs.text: Page Reference: [docs/basic-considerations.md]

docs.title: Design Principles
docs.text:
APIs are designed with the following principles in mind:

  • Consistency: Common patterns for naming, structure, filtering, and error handling are used across APIs.
  • Explicit Contracts: APIs are treated as contracts. Backward compatibility is preserved wherever possible, and breaking changes are explicitly versioned and documented.
  • Integration-First: APIs are optimised for system-to-system integration rather than UI consumption.
  • Security by Default: APIs require authentication and authorisation. Access is scoped and auditable.
  • Observability: APIs are designed to support logging, tracing, and monitoring at scale.

docs.title: Interaction Models (Flows)
docs.text: APIs support both Synchronous and Asynchronous integration flows, depending on the nature of the operation and the underlying business process.

docs.title: Synchronous Models
docs.text:
Synchronous flows are used where an immediate, deterministic response is required. These typically follow a request/response pattern over HTTP and are suitable for validations, reads, and transactional operations where the outcome is known at request time.

sequenceDiagram

    participant Client
    participant Integration
    participant Navigator
    participant External


    Navigator->>+Integration: Workflows
    Integration->>External: 
    External->>Integration: 
    Integration->>-Navigator: 

    rect rgb(0, 255, 0) 
        Client->>Integration: Initiation
        Integration->>Client: Completion
        Note over Integration,Client: 200 OK: {uuid}
    end
  1. Initiation: Start with this Introduction section
  2. Acknowledgement: Review authentication and environment setup
  3. Processing: Process orchestration and dependency decomposition are complementary techniques used to manage, automate, and optimize complex, multi-step business or technical processes.
  4. Notification: Refer to the Releases section to track changes
  5. Confirmation: Navigate to the relevant API domain
  6. Processing: Refer to the Releases section to track changes

docs.title: Asynchronous Models
docs.text:
Asynchronous flows are used for long-running, stateful, or multi-step processes common in logistics (e.g. orchestration, external dependencies, or downstream processing). In these cases, the API acknowledges the request and processing continues out of band, with state changes communicated via ESB1 events, SOA2 decision components, callbacks, or polling endpoints.

sequenceDiagram

    participant Client
    participant Integration
    participant Navigator
    participant External


    rect rgb(0, 255, 0) 
        Client->>+Integration: Initiation
        Integration-->>Client: Acknowledgement
        Note over Integration,Client: 202 Accepted: {uuid}
    end
    Note over Integration,Navigator: Orchestration &<br/> decomposition
    Integration->>Navigator: Workflows
    Navigator->>Integration: 
    Integration->>External: 
    External->>Integration: 
    Integration->>Navigator: 
    Navigator->>Integration: 
    Note over Integration,Navigator: Orchestration <br/>& composition
    rect rgb(0, 255, 0) 
        Integration->>-Client: Completion
    end
  1. Initiation: Start with this Introduction section
  2. Acknowledgement: Review authentication and environment setup
  3. Processing: Process orchestration and dependency decomposition are complementary techniques used to manage, automate, and optimize complex, multi-step business or technical processes.
  4. Notification: Refer to the Releases section to track changes
  5. Confirmation: Navigate to the relevant API domain
  6. Processing: Refer to the Releases section to track changes
  7. Completion: Refer to the Releases section to track changes
  8. Processing: Refer to the Releases section to track changes
  9. Completion: Refer to the Releases section to track changes

Both models may coexist within the same domain. Each API explicitly documents which interaction model it uses and how consumers are expected to track state, handle retries, and react to eventual completion or failure. Consumers should design integrations assuming eventual consistency where asynchronous flows are involved.

docs.title: Terminology
docs.text:
The following terms are used consistently throughout the documentation:

Term Description API Consumer Any system or service that invokes Navigator APIs Resource A business entity exposed by the API (e.g. Order, Shipment, Document) Endpoint A specific HTTP path and method used to interact with a resource Payload The JSON body sent in a request or returned in a response Version The version identifier of an API or release Release A published set of API changes deployed to an environment

Additional domain-specific terminology is defined within each API section where relevant.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
Page Reference: [docs/design-principles]

  1. Enterprise Service Bus is a messaging service. It acts as a messaging backbone for applications and implements a communication system in a Service Oriented Architecture (SOA)2. It represents a software architecture for distributed computing. ↩

  2. Service Oriented Architecture is an architectural style that focuses on discrete services. Each service is a discrete unit of functionality that can be accessed remotely and acted upon and updated independently. SOA is also intended to be independent of vendors, products and technologies. ↩↩

docs.title: References

docs.title: Onboarding Overview
docs.text: This section outlines the standard onboarding process for clients integrating with the Navigator APIs. The onboarding flow is designed to ensure that access is provisioned correctly, responsibilities are clearly defined, and integrations can progress efficiently from initial setup to production use.

docs.title: Initiating the Integration
docs.text:
To begin the onboarding process, the client should contact their Navigator account representative or integration contact to initiate an internal API onboarding request.

The following information is required to proceed:

  • APIs or functional domains to be integrated (e.g. Orders, Shipments, Tracking, Financials, Documents)
  • Primary technical contact responsible for the integration
  • Target go-live date or expected timeline

This information is used to scope the integration and prepare the required access and configuration.

docs.title: Access Provisioning
docs.text:
Once the request is submitted, an internal onboarding ticket is created and assigned to the Navigator integration team.

An integration analyst will:

  • Coordinate with the client’s technical contact
  • Provision authentication credentials for the requested environments
  • Confirm API scope and access permissions
  • Provide guidance and support throughout the integration lifecycle

The integration team remains the primary point of contact until the integration is ready for production use.

docs.title: Prerequisites and Expectations
docs.text:
The following prerequisites must be satisfied to ensure a successful integration:

  • The integration is based on direct API consumption (REST) with an active contract to access exposed resources
  • The client has prior experience working with RESTful APIs
  • The client is familiar with JSON request and response payloads

Meeting these prerequisites helps ensure a smoother onboarding process and reduces integration lead time.

docs.title: References
docs.text: Page Reference: [docs/onboarding-overview.md]

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
The Client Invoices API provides read access to invoice data issued to a client within Navigator.

This API category is intended for partner systems that need to:

  • Retrieve a list of open financial obligations (e.g. pending or unpaid invoices)
  • Fetch detailed invoice data for reconciliation, reporting, or downstream processing

The API is read-only and exposes invoice data in structured JSON format. All endpoints follow the global conventions defined in the Introduction, including authentication, versioning, and error handling.

docs.title: Available Endpoints
docs.text:
This category currently exposes the following endpoints:

  • List Client Invoices Returns the list of all invoices for a client matching specific status criteria (e.g. date of issuance).

  • Get Invoice Details Retrieve the full details of a single invoice by its identifier.

Each endpoint documents its supported interaction model, parameters, and response schema in detail.

docs.title: Interaction Model
docs.text:
All Client Invoices endpoints are synchronous and follow a standard HTTP request/response pattern.

Responses reflect the current state of the invoice data at request time. No asynchronous processing or event emission is involved in this API category.

docs.title: Notes and Constraints
docs.text:
• Only invoices visible to the authenticated client context are returned
  • Filtering is limited to documented query parameters
  • The API does not support invoice creation, updates, or payment actions

Any behaviour not explicitly documented should be considered unsupported.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
The Client Invoices API exposes read-only access to invoice data issued to a client.

It allows consumers to:

  • Discover open financial obligations
  • Retrieve structured invoice data for downstream processing
  • Integrate invoice visibility into reconciliation or reporting workflows

All endpoints in this category are synchronous, scoped to the authenticated client, and follow the global API conventions mentioned also in the Introduction.

docs.title: References
docs.text: Page Reference: [docs/apis/client-invoice/index.md]

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Retrieve the list of invoices and credit notes associated with the authenticated client.

This endpoint is typically used to:

  • Display outstanding invoices
  • Trigger reconciliation or payment workflows
  • Periodically sync invoice metadata into downstream systems

docs.title: Endpoint
docs.text:
OperationCommand

GET /oapi/ci/invoices

GET /oapi/ci/invoices HTTP/1.1

docs.title: Headers
docs.text:
Important

* Required header keys

Key Description ApplicationId* Unique identifier, assigned per application, provided to access the set of API services string AuthenticationKey* Token string DateIssued Filter string (ISO 8601) Debug Verbosity level integer

docs.title: Request
docs.text:
Environment MOCKTESTLIVE 
curl -X GET "https://mock.api.swift-navigator.com/oapi/ci/invoices" \
-H "ApplicationId: <id>" \
-H "AuthenticationKey: <token>" \
-H "Accept: application/json"

curl -X GET "https://test.api.swift-navigator.com/oapi/ci/invoices" \
-H "ApplicationId: <id>" \
-H "AuthenticationKey: <token>" \
-H "Accept: application/json"

curl -X GET "https://live.api.swift-navigator.com/oapi/ci/invoices" \
-H "ApplicationId: <id>" \
-H "AuthenticationKey: <token>" \
-H "Accept: application/json"

docs.title: Response
Summary
docs.text:
The List Invoices endpoint provides a filtered view of a client’s pending invoices and credit notes.

It is intended for:

  • Periodic synchronisation of invoice metadata
  • Triggering external payment or reconciliation processes
  • Presenting outstanding invoices in client-facing systems

The endpoint is synchronous, read-only, and returns only invoices visible within the authenticated client context.

docs.title: References
docs.text: Page Reference: [docs/apis/client-invoice/list-invoices.md]

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Retrieve the full JSON representation of a specific invoice or credit note associated with the authenticated client.

This endpoint is typically used to:

  • Inspect invoice details at line level
  • Validate amounts, taxes, and dates
  • Reconcile invoices with accounting or ERP systems
  • Retrieve structured data behind an invoice reference number

docs.title: Endpoint
docs.text:
OperationCommand

GET /oapi/ci/invoice/{invoiceReferenceNumber}

GET /oapi/ci/invoice/{invoiceReferenceNumber} HTTP/1.1

docs.title: Headers
docs.text:
Important

* Required header keys

Key Description ApplicationId* Unique identifier, assigned per application, provided to access the set of API services string AuthenticationKey* Token string Debug Verbosity level integer

docs.title: Request
docs.text:
Environment MOCKTESTLIVE 
curl -X GET "https://mock.api.swift-navigator.com/oapi/ci/invoice/{invoiceReferenceNumber}" \
-H "ApplicationId: <id>" \
-H "AuthenticationKey: <token>" \
-H "Accept: application/json"

curl -X GET "https://test.api.swift-navigator.com/oapi/ci/invoice/{invoiceReferenceNumber}" \
-H "ApplicationId: <id>" \
-H "AuthenticationKey: <token>" \
-H "Accept: application/json"

curl -X GET "https://live.api.swift-navigator.com/oapi/ci/invoice/{invoiceReferenceNumber}" \
-H "ApplicationId: <id>" \
-H "AuthenticationKey: <token>" \
-H "Accept: application/json"

                    "documentNumber": "3634107",
                    "orders": [
                        {
                            "id": 3634107,
                            "poNumber": "Intercon / FOZX97-15",
                            "flags": []
                        }
                    ],
                    "flags": []
                }
            ],
            "documentUrl": "https://cdn.swift-navigator.com/api/documents/d/yGnBTCqNteN"
        }
    }
}
Information
  • invoiceReferenceNumber is the reference number of each invoice issued.
  • documentUrl contains the public address of the invoice in PDF format and will remain available for download for up to two (2) months after issuance. The URL exists also in the List of Invoices API.
Client Error

Response 401 Unauthorized Response 405 Method Not Allowed Response 429 Too Many Requests

{
    "error": " ... "
}
Server Error

Response 500 Internal Server Error Response 502 Bad Gateway Response 503 Service Unavailable

{
    "error": " ... "
}

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
The Retrieve Invoice endpoint provides the complete, structured JSON payload for a single invoice or credit note.

It is intended for:

  • Detailed invoice inspection
  • Accounting and ERP reconciliation
  • Validation of totals, VAT, and line items
  • Programmatic access to invoice metadata and documents
  • The endpoint is synchronous, read-only, and operates strictly within the scope of the authenticated client.

docs.title: References
docs.text: Page Reference: [docs/apis/client-invoice/retrieve-invoice.md]

docs.title: Release Overview
docs.text:
This release represents the initial alpha version of the Navigator API documentation and platform.

The scope of this release is intentionally limited and focused on validating the API structure, documentation conventions, and end-to-end integration flow.

At this release, only the Client Invoices of the Financials API is available.

docs.title: Release Scope
docs.text: The following API domain is included in this Alpha-0.2026 release:

docs.title: Financials
docs.text:
Client Invoice API

The Client Invoice API enables consumers to retrieve invoice data generated within Navigator. The API is read-only in this release and supports invoice discovery and retrieval use cases.

Available endpoints:

  • List all pending client invoices
  • Retrieve a specific client invoice

docs.title: List Client Invoices
docs.text:
Provides a paginated list of client invoices based on the available filtering and sorting criteria.

Typical use cases include:

  • Invoice reconciliation
  • Financial reporting
  • Downstream accounting system synchronisation

Refer to the documentation: Client Invoice / List of Invoices

docs.title: Retrieve an Invoice
docs.text:
Retrieves the full details of a single client invoice using its unique identifier.

This endpoint is intended for:

  • Viewing invoice details
  • Auditing and verification
  • Detailed financial processing

Refer to the documentation: Client Invoice / Retrieve an Invoice

docs.title: Limitations and Notes
docs.text:
The following limitations apply to this alpha release:

  • Only Client Invoice APIs are available
  • Write operations are not supported
  • API contracts may change without prior notice
  • Error handling and edge cases may evolve between alpha releases

docs.title: Target Audience
docs.text:
This release is intended for:

  • Early integrators
  • Internal validation
  • Feedback on API structure and documentation clarity

docs.title: Feedback and Next Steps
docs.text:
Feedback collected during the alpha phase will be used to:

  • Refine API contracts
  • Improve documentation consistency
  • Expand coverage to additional domains

Subsequent releases will introduce additional APIs and capabilities.

docs.title: References
docs.text: Page Reference: [docs/releases/0.2026.md]
